user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_count_lock:
```c
static void
MHD_ip_count_lock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex);
#else
  (void) daemon;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_ip_count_lock:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS 1
...
#define MHD_mutex_lock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_lock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to lock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: mhd_assert is defined as ((void)0), so the statement mhd_assert(NULL == daemon->master); expands to a no-op expression statement ((void)0); which is reachable and does not introduce unreachable code. (Note: if mhd_assert were defined to a non-returning construct such as an infinite loop or abort, that could create unreachable code after it, but with the given definition there is no violation.)
